Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support as it is based on a local government issuance in Baybay City and does not apply to the entire country.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that the lifting of restrictions on basketball games in Baybay City applies to the entire country, which is not true.
Exist alternative explanation: There is an alternative explanation that only professional basketball games were allowed by the Inter-Agency Task Force on Emerging Infectious Diseases, according to the Philippine health undersecretary.
Contradict fact: The claim contradicts the fact that sports events were prohibited in the Philippines as part of the government measures to curb coronavirus infections, as stated in April 2020.
Understate: It can be argued that the claim understates the restrictions imposed on basketball games in the Philippines, as it only focuses on the lifting of restrictions in Baybay City and does not provide a comprehensive overview of the nationwide situation.
Exaggerate: There is no evidence of exaggeration in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim falters at times by not providing accurate information about the restrictions on basketball games in the Philippines and by falsely implying that the restrictions have been lifted for the entire country.
